title: Russell Watson discusses his lust for life on Loose Women | Daily Mail Online
text: Share 204 shares He said: 'The first song I wrote was poignantly called ‘I’m alive’ which is about when I was diagnosed. 'My headaches had got worse and I went to see a specialist and I got the news and it was an out of body experience so the lyrics really describe that moment. 'It was quite cathartic, I felt I’d drawn a line under it but even 10 years later people still want to talk about. Looking good: The classical singer's battle to overcome two brain tumours has been well documented but Loose Women viewers couldn't believe how well the star, 50, looked during Tuesday's show 'The meaning of songs intensified after the illness, Ava Maria had real significance. 'The second tumour nearly finished my life and when I performed it and the tears were streaming down my face but the audience really engaged with it.' He added that brain tumour survivors still wrote to him and he was happy to respond. The popular singer drew many compliments from viewers, with one writing: 'If I may be so bold, I think you look amazing for 50!' Kind words: The popular singer drew many compliments from viewers Shocked: One was stunned not to have noticed before Complimentary: The singer will no doubt be thrilled by the comments While another gushed: 'I did not even realise how bloody gorgeous u r! How have I missed this!?!?! Lol x' As a third said: '@russellthevoice looks fab for 50!' Russell appeared on Loose Women last November and told how he had a premonition of his illness as a child. He explained: 'I used to have nightmares about explosions in my head. 'It’s a bit weird – when I was a kid I used to have nightmares about explosions in my head. 'So, when I was sat being told I had this great big lump in my skull I knew this [the haemorrhage] was going to happen.'
